item.title: Trump Faces $2 Trillion Hurdle to Win Money From Saudi Prince
item.description: US President Donald Trump’s hopes of securing as much as $1 trillion in investment commitments from Saudi Arabia might clash with another costly ambition - transforming the kingdom’s own economy.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Martin, Zainab Fattah

media:content.media:description: An illustration of Neom's planned Line Development, provided in March 2024.

item.title: India Proposes First Counter Move Against Trump’s Tariff Regime
item.description: India has proposed levies on some US goods in response to Washington’s duties on steel and aluminum, marking its first retaliation against President Donald Trump’s tariff regime, even as the two countries move closer to finalizing a trade deal.
item.dc:creator: Shruti Srivastava

media:content.media:description: A crane is used to load stainless steel coils onto a train container at Jindal Stainless Ltd. plant in Jajpur, Odisha, India, on Thursday, April 24, 2025. India is scheduled to release industrial production figures on April 28. Photographer: Anindito Mukherjee/Bloomberg

item.title: The Problem With the Fed Isn’t Independence, It’s Accountability
item.description: Monetary policy is too technical to be left to the politicians and too political to be left to the technocrats.
item.dc:creator: Tom Orlik

media:content.media:description: Photographer: Scott Semler for Bloomberg Businessweek. Prop Stylist: Andrea Bonin

item.title: US Small-Business Optimism Declines for a Fourth Straight Month
item.description: Sentiment among US small businesses deteriorated for a fourth straight month in April as firms grew more downbeat about the economic outlook and sales prospects amid higher tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Nazmul Ahasan

media:content.media:description: Businesses in the Flushing, in the Queens borough of New York.

item.title: UK Firms Cut Jobs for Third Month as Tax Hike, Trade War Hit
item.description: British businesses cut jobs for a third straight month in April as a £26 billion ($34 billion) tax hike took effect and Donald Trump’s tariffs darkened the global economic outlook.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Atkinson, Tom Rees

media:content.media:description: Commuters in London.

item.title: Swiss Outlook Cut at UBS With Warning on Trump’s Pharma Push
item.description: UBS Group AG cut its forecast for expansion in Switzerland this year and warned that Donald Trump’s pressure on drugmakers poses a long-term threat to one of its biggest drivers of growth.
item.dc:creator: Levin Stamm

media:content.media:description: Commuters pass a UBS Group AG bank branch in Zurich.

item.title: South Africa’s Unemployment Rate Jumps as Trade Hemorrhages Jobs
item.description: South Africa’s unemployment rate rose more than expected in the first quarter as the construction and trade sectors shed jobs.
item.dc:creator: Katlego Mtshali, S'thembile Cele

media:content.media:description: A worker prepares a steel automobile panel part at a manufacturing plant in Durban.

item.title: German Investor Confidence Jumps on Progress Over Tariffs
item.description: Investor confidence in Germany’s economy improved as the initial shock from US tariffs fades and a new government prepares to boost public spending.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Weber

item.title: US Treasuries Gain as Traders Eye Inflation for Clues on Fed
item.description: Treasuries gained ahead of the release of US inflation data, paring sharp losses sparked by the temporary US-China trade truce that’s dimmed the odds of a global recession.
item.dc:creator: Liz Capo McCormick

item.title: ECB Officials Urge Scenario Analysis to Cope With Trade Turmoil
item.description: The European Central Bank shouldn’t rely too much on its baseline outlook and must be prepared to react quickly if economic growth and inflation diverge from expectations, according to two Governing Council members.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers, Alexander Weber

media:content.media:description: The headquarters of the European Central Bank beyond a freight terminal in Frankfurt. Photographer: Alex Kraus/Bloomberg

item.title: EU Plagued by ‘Collective Action Problem’ on Trade, Bessent Says
item.description: US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said the European Union suffers from a “collective action problem” that’s hampering trade negotiations, downplaying the possibility of a quick agreement with the US’s largest trading relationship.
item.dc:creator: Jordan Fabian

media:content.media:description: Scott Bessent

item.title: India Denies Trump’s Suggestion He Used Trade to Secure Truce
item.description: Indian officials denied that trade with the US was used as a bargaining chip in a just-concluded ceasefire between India and Pakistan, contradicting statements by President Donald Trump that the US offered to trade more with both countries if they stopped hostilities.
item.dc:creator: Santosh Kumar, Sudhi Ranjan Sen, Dan Strumpf

media:content.media:description: An Indian man watches the live telecast of Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's speech on television screens, in Prayagraj, in the northern Indian state of Uttar Pradesh, India, Monday, May 12, 2025. (AP Photo/Rajesh Kumar Singh) Photographer: Rajesh Kumar Singh/AP

item.title: SALT, Tips and Auto Loans: A Guide to the House GOP Tax Bill
item.description: House Republicans’ release of the tax provisions in their massive fiscal bill provides a crucial initial reading of what party leaders think could pass, culminating weeks of intense negotiations among fractious GOP lawmakers.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Emily Birnbaum

media:content.media:description: Customers at a Ford dealership in Richmond, California, US, on Wednesday, April 16, 2025. US retail sales rose substantially in March on a jump in car purchases and other goods such as electronics, suggesting consumers were scrambling to get ahead of tariffs.

item.title: Thailand Submits Proposals to US to Get Tariff Talks Started
item.description: Thailand has submitted a range of proposals to the US on how it plans to boost imports and promote investments, the latest bid by the Southeast Asian nation to nudge the Trump administration to begin formal talks over a planned 36% tariff on exports.
item.dc:creator: Patpicha Tanakasempipat

media:content.media:description: A container ship at Bangkok Port.

item.title: Xi Courts Latin America as Trump’s Tariffs Pressure Region
item.description: Chinese President Xi Jinping vowed to deepen economic cooperation with Latin American and Caribbean nations and offered visa-free entry to some countries, as he seeks to position China as a better partner than the US.
item.dc:creator: Colum Murphy, Jing Li

media:content.media:description: China's President Xi Jinping speaks during the opening ceremony of the Fourth Ministerial Meeting of the Forum of China and Community of Latin American and Caribbean States (CELAC), in Beijing on May 13, 2025. (Photo by Pedro Pardo / AFP) (Photo by PEDRO PARDO/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Romanian Inflation Stays Flat as Political Risks Cloud Outlook
item.description: Romanian inflation remained unchanged last month as the gravest political crisis since the collapse of communism pushed the leu to a record low which will likely intensify price pressure and complicate the central bank’s wait-and-see approach to monetary policy in the coming month.
item.dc:creator: Andra Timu

item.title: China Removes Ban on Boeing Deliveries After US Trade Truce
item.description: China has removed a month-long ban on airlines taking delivery of Boeing Co. planes, according to people familiar with the matter, following a breakthrough in trade talks with the US that temporarily slashed tariffs on each side.
item.dc:creator: Danny Lee

media:content.media:description: An employee works on the wing of a Boeing Next Generation 737 jet on an assembly line at Boeing's manufacturing facility in Renton, Washington, U.S., on Wednesday, Oct. 27, 2010. Boeing Co. kept production of the 737, the world's most widely flown plane, steady through the recession and plans to increase it by more than 20 percent over the span of a year starting in 2012.

item.title: Slovakia, Hungary Seen Among Worst Hit by Tariffs, EBRD Says
item.description: Eastern European countries are expected to be among the economies worst hit by risks related to trade tariffs, according to the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development.
item.dc:creator: Jorgelina Do Rosario

item.title: Foreigners’ Interest in US Job Postings Slumps in Indeed Data
item.description: The burst of foreign interest in US jobs following the Covid-19 pandemic has all but vanished, a shift that threatens to exacerbate labor shortages in industries such as health care.
item.dc:creator: Nazmul Ahasan, Augusta Saraiva

media:content.media:description: Registered nurses care for patients in Torrance, California, in 2021. Photographer: Mario Tama/Getty Images

item.title: Chinese Rare Earth Firms Ask for Official Clarity on US Exports
item.description: Chinese rare-earth exporters are asking the government to clarify whether they’re allowed to sell to the US, after Beijing and Washington called a ceasefire in their trade war.
item.dc:creator: Jason Rogers

media:content.media:description: Bags of rare earth concentrates sit for transport at the Mountain Pass mine, operated by MP Materials, in Mountain Pass, California, U.S., on Friday, June 7, 2019. America's only rare earths producer, MP Materials, has been shipping all its output from the Mountain Pass mine in California to China because there is currently no refining capacity available to handle its production anywhere else in the world, its biggest shareholder said last month. Photographer: Joe Buglewicz/Bloomberg

item.title: Nomura Turns Bullish on China’s Stocks After Trade Truce With US
item.description: Nomura Holdings Inc. strategists upgraded Chinese stocks to a ‘tactical overweight,’ saying the trade truce between the US and China is a significant positive for the Asian nation’s equities.
item.dc:creator: Abhishek Vishnoi

media:content.media:description: Signage outside a branch of Nomura Securities Co. Photographer: Kiyoshi Ota/Bloomberg

item.title: BOJ Still Eyeing Rate Hikes While Wary of Tariffs, Summary Shows
item.description: Bank of Japan board members signaled their intention for further rate hikes while citing the need to stay vigilant due the potential economic impacts from US tariff measures, according to a summary of opinions from their April 30-May 1 meeting.
item.dc:creator: Toru Fujioka

media:content.media:description: A Japanese flag flies outside the Bank of Japan (BOJ) headquarters in Tokyo.

item.title: Tariffs Create World Challenges, Opportunities, WTO Head Says
item.description: The global trade war with its persistent barrage of tariff developments provides both challenges and opportunities, according to Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala, the Director General of the World Trade Organisation.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara

media:content.media:description: Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala Photographer: Samuel Corum/Bloomberg

item.title: Australia’s Business Conditions Ease, Boosting Case for RBA Cuts
item.description: Australian business conditions eased in April as profitability weakened, forward orders slipped and firms’ spending plans took a hit, boosting the case for the Reserve Bank to cut interest rates to support the economy.
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey

item.title: US Inflation Seen Picking Up in April With Modest Tariffs Impact
item.description: US inflation likely accelerated in April after an unexpected cooldown the previous month, with higher tariffs on Chinese goods in particular starting to impact prices.
item.dc:creator: Augusta Saraiva

item.title: New Yorkers Vow to Block House GOP Tax Bill Over SALT Limit
item.description: Two New York Republican lawmakers promised to block their party’s signature tax legislation unless GOP leaders raise a proposed $30,000 limit on the federal income tax deduction for state and local taxes.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Nacha Cattan

media:content.media:description: The US Capitol in Washington, DC.

item.title: Lula and Xi to Ink New Deals as Brazil Shrugs Off Trump’s Trade Threats
item.description: Brazil’s Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva insists he doesn’t want to pick between the US and China as his two largest trading partners wage a trade war. But it’s increasingly clear which side he’d choose if forced.
item.dc:creator: Simone Iglesias, Leonardo Lara, Daniel Carvalho

media:content.media:description: Xi Jinping and Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva in 2024.

item.title: US-China Truce Likely to Avert Recession But Not Coming Slowdown
item.description: The Trump administration’s temporary trade deal with China didn’t arrive in time to prevent a slowdown in the US economy, forecasters say, even if it reduces the risk of a full-blown recession later this year.
item.dc:creator: Jarrell Dillard, Jonnelle Marte

media:content.media:description: The YM Welcome container ship docked at the Port of Long Beach in Long Beach, California, US, on Monday, April 28, 2025. Since the US raised levies on China to 145% in early April, cargo shipments have plummeted, perhaps by as much as 60%, according to one estimate.

item.title: GOP to Phase Out Biden Energy Credits to Pay for Tax Cuts
item.description: House Republicans are proposing to eliminate a tax credit for electric vehicles and phase out incentives to develop clean-energy projects to help pay for President Donald Trump’s massive tax package.
item.dc:creator: Ari Natter

media:content.media:description: A driver unplugs an electric vehicle charging station in Hudson, New York.

item.title: Traders See Fed Cutting Rates Just Twice in 2025 on Cooling Trade War
item.description: Traders lowered their bets on the Federal Reserve’s interest-rate cuts this year, pricing in just two reductions for 2025 after the US and China agreed to cut tariffs and moderate their trade war.
item.dc:creator: Michael Mackenzie
